chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a child with suspected cow's milk allergy?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
If a diagnosis of cow's milk allergy is suspected on the basis of reported or observed clinical features, assess the child to help distinguish between IgE- and non-IgE-mediated allergy, and manage appropriately.

  • Take an allergy-focused history by asking about:
    • The symptoms, severity, frequency, speed of onset, duration, and the timing of the reaction in relation to cow's milk exposure. A food and symptom diary may be helpful.
      • Symptoms usually develop within a week of cow's milk introduction, although they may be delayed for several weeks.
      • Reactions may be triggered by food ingestion, inhalation, or skin contact (rare).
    • The form in which milk has been ingested (fresh, processed, cooked, or baked), and the quantity.
      • The trigger is usually cow's milk, however, it may be cow's milk protein in maternal breast milk in infants who are exclusively breastfed (rare in IgE-mediated allergy).
      • IgE-mediated reactions usually occur following a small amount of milk, whereas non-IgE-mediated reactions usually occur after ingestion of larger volumes of milk.
    • Any uneventful exposures to cow's milk before or after the reaction.
    • The setting of reactions (such as school or home).
    • The reproducibility of symptoms on repeated cow's milk exposure.
    • The age when symptoms started, the child's feeding history (age of complementary feeding [weaning], breast- or formula-fed), weight gain, and nutritional status.
      • Most affected children present by six months of age; onset is rare after 12 months of age.
      • If the child is currently being breastfed, ask about the mother’s diet.
    • Any comorbid atopic conditions such as asthma, eczema, or allergic rhinitis; any history of other food allergies. See the CKS topics on Asthma, Eczema - atopic, Allergic rhinitis, and Food allergy for more information.
    • Any family history of food allergy or atopic conditions, particularly in parents and siblings.
    • Any symptom response to dietary restrictions or reintroduction of cow's milk, and/or medications tried, such as oral antihistamines.
  • Examine the child for:
    • Nutritional status and growth, including weight, length/height, and calculation of body mass index (BMI).
    • Any signs of a clinical reaction.
    • Any signs of comorbid conditions such as atopic eczema, asthma, and/or allergic rhinitis. See the CKS topics on Eczema - atopic, Asthma, and Allergic rhinitis for more information.
    • Any signs suggesting an alternative diagnosis.
  • Consider arranging skin prick testing and/or serum-specific IgE allergy testing if there is suspected IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy, depending on local referral pathways and availability.
    • Be aware that there are no reliable allergy tests to confirm the diagnosis of non-IgE-mediated allergy.
  • Advise the parents/carers that the following diagnostic tools are not recommended for the diagnosis of cow's milk allergy:
    • Serum-specific immunoglobulin (Ig)G testing.
    • Vega testing (electroacupuncture devices).
    • Applied kinesiology (muscle strength testing).
    • Hair analysis (assessing mineral content).
    • Atopy patch testing.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on assessment are largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Food allergy in under 19s: assessment and diagnosis [NICE, 2018], the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health (RCPCH) publication Allergy care pathways for children. Food allergy [RCPCH, 2011], the British Society for Allergy and Clinical Immunology (BSACI) publication BSACI guideline for the diagnosis and management of cow's milk allergy [Luyt et al, 2014], the European Academy of Allergy and Clinical Immunology (EAACI) publications Food Allergy and Anaphylaxis Guidelines [Muraro, 2014] and Diagnosis and management of non‐IgE gastrointestinal allergies in breastfed infants - an EAACI Position Paper [Meyer, 2019]; the World Allergy Organization publication Diagnosis and rationale for action against cow's milk allergy (DRACMA): a summary report [Fiocchi et al, 2010], the European Society for Paediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition (ESPGHAN) guidelines Diagnostic approach and management of cow’s-milk protein allergy in infants and children [Koletzko et al, 2012], the International Collaboration in Asthma, Allergy and Immunology consensus document ICON: Food allergy [Burks, 2012], the US National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) Guidelines for the diagnosis and management of food allergy in the United States [Boyce, 2010], and expert opinion in review articles on food allergy [Steele, 2014], on cow's milk allergy in children [Ludman et al, 2013], on non-IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy [Venter et al, 2013; Venter, 2017], and in the updated Milk Allergy in Primary Care (MAP) guideline [Fox, 2019].

Taking an allergy-focused clinical history

  • The elements of taking an allergy-focused clinical history are largely based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014], the RCPCH publication [RCPCH, 2011], the EAACI guidelines [Muraro, 2014; Meyer, 2019], the NIAID guidelines [Boyce, 2010], and expert opinion in review articles [Ludman et al, 2013; Steele, 2014; Venter, 2017].
    • The NICE clinical guideline found limited evidence for the use of an allergy-focused history, however the guideline development group (GDG) felt this would reduce the chance of misdiagnosis of food allergy.
    • The information on the expected onset of symptoms after milk introduction is based on the BSACI guideline.
    • The recommendation to consider use of a food and symptom diary is extrapolated from expert opinion in the RCPCH publication.
    • The information that reactions may be triggered by food ingestion, inhalation, or skin contact is based on the EAACI guideline on food allergy and anaphylaxis.
    • The information that IgE-mediated allergy is rare in exclusively breastfed infants and children is based on the updated MAP guideline.
    • The information on the typical quantities of milk required to cause symptoms is based on the BSACI guideline.
    • The recommendation to ask about any uneventful exposures to the suspected food allergen is based on the fact that there may be a dose-dependent threshold for reactivity. It may also highlight incorrectly identified food triggers [Boyce, 2010; Steele, 2014].
    • The information on the typical age of presentation is based on the BSACI guideline.
    • The recommendation to ask about family history of atopy affecting first-degree relatives is based on the NICE clinical guideline and expert opinion in a review article [Venter, 2017].

Performing a physical examination

  • The recommendations on physical examination are based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the EAACI guideline [Muraro, 2014], the NIAID guidelines [Boyce, 2010], and expert opinion in a review article [Venter, 2017].
    • The NICE guideline development group (GDG) noted that although food allergies do not always affect growth, a child's growth and nutrition should be checked, along with the presence of atopic co-morbidities.
    • This approach is supported by the EAACI guideline and expert opinion in a review article [Venter, 2017].
  • The recommendation to examine the child for signs indicating an alternative diagnosis is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice. This approach is also supported by the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.

Arranging allergy testing

  • The recommendation to arrange skin prick testing and/or serum-specific immunoglobulin (Ig)E allergy testing is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the EAACI guidelines [Muraro, 2014], the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014], the ICON consensus document [Burks, 2012], the NIAID guidelines [Boyce, 2010], the RCPCH publication [RCPCH, 2011], and expert opinion in a review article [Steele, 2014].
    • The NICE clinical guideline highlights that allergy testing should only be offered if appropriate, after an allergy-focused history has been taken. In addition, it states that accurate identification of true food allergy will help to reduce the incidence of adverse reactions, and reduce unnecessary dietary exclusion of foods that are safe and should be eaten as part of a normal, healthy diet.
    • The NICE clinical guideline found low-quality evidence that skin prick testing and serum-specific IgE testing were similar in their diagnostic performance. Health economic analysis found that both tests were more cost-effective than no test in diagnosing suspected IgE-mediated allergy.
    • The EAACI guidelines note that overall, skin prick testing and serum-specific IgE testing appear sensitive though not specific for diagnosing IgE-mediated food allergy.
    • The BSACI guideline highlights that a history of allergic symptoms after cow's milk exposure together with evidence of sensitization on allergy testing allows the diagnosis of IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy to be made.
  • The information that there are no reliable allergy tests to confirm the diagnosis of non-IgE-mediated allergy is based on the World Allergy Organization publication [Fiocchi et al, 2010] and expert opinion in review articles [Ludman et al, 2013; Venter, 2017].

Diagnostic tests not recommended

  • The information on the diagnostic tests not recommended for the diagnosis of cow's milk allergy is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014], the EAACI guidelines [Muraro, 2014; Meyer, 2019], the ESPGHAN guidelines [Koletzko et al, 2012], the NIAID guidelines [Boyce, 2010], and expert opinion in review articles [Ludman et al, 2013].
    • The NICE clinical guideline found no good-quality evidence or well-designed studies supporting the use of alternative diagnostic tools in suspected IgE-mediated food allergy.
